structure.value: Let's get to know each other
hello_romans

Welcome to Mendelevi - our chemistry application, and your friend in Science world!
Here, you'll embark on an exciting journey to explore the fascinating chemistry world and chemical elements.
laboratory_journey
Learning all chemical elements from the periodic table is possible!

To start learning a random element that our application has automatically selected for you from our collection of ancient scrolls, click on the big 'Learn' button on start screen and you will be taken to the infarmation screen with the all necessary information that we have prepared.
scrolls

Here's what the 'Learn' button should look like. If you happen to notice it's not where it should be, please let us know, and we might just have to retrain our developers to become elephant trainers instead.
learn_btn_image
Each element is presented with detailed information about its physical and chemical properties, the story behind its discovery, and additional reference details.
single_scroll

Take your time, read thoughtfully. Try to associate what you read with something familiar to you, make notes, draw non-standard schemes. The more you understand, the less you will have to memorize, although undoubtedly memorize will come and a lot.  If you are trying to understand or memorize something, say it out loud.
roman_learn
Once you have finished reading about a specific element, you'll have the opportunity to test your knowledge through a quiz, specially for that our designer draw another important button 'Memorize'.
memorize_btn_image

Most importantly, relax, you are not in an exam, and we are not an angry supervisor who demands something from you. It is better to imagine that we are somewhere on the rostrum of the ancient Roman Colosseum discussing how flat our Earth is and how fast other planets revolve around it. The main thing to remember is that there are no final truths in science, and all great things start from small.
romans_discussing

Our goal is to help you memorize the necessary information, so the correct answer will be highlighted in green and if you answered incorrectly, you will most likely see the same question in the same Memorizing session. In these questions, only one answer choice is correct. At the end of the session we will make sure to show your result.
composite_stars

If the learned items counter has moved from 0, you are on the right way! Keep up the good work, but don't forget about practicing repetition. Especially for this purpose we did not remove the ‚Äúrepeat‚Äù button, when you click on it, a lesson is generated to repeat the most previously learned element. And remember that practice makes perfect!

Despite the fact that there are already more than 100 varieties of periodic tables, our application allows you to explore what we consider the four most important ones: ‚ÄúShort Polyatomic,‚Äù ‚ÄúWide Polyatomic,‚Äù ‚ÄúClassic,‚Äù and ‚ÄúStandard.‚Äù As the application develops, we will add other types of periodic tables to this section.
standard_table_example
(example of the standard representation of periodic table)
Each of the visual representations has its own settings for the table scale, during the change of which the displayed information about the item dynamically changes.
element_sizes_example
As you can see when zooming in, the view is enhanced with additional information. These are optionally displayed item parameters that the user can select at any time.
swap_parameters
Obviously try to scale the element size and swap the optional parameter later.
phase_example
From optional parameter density to density for example.
density_example
All views are interactive and have their own memory that memorizes the user's position on the table, as well as the selected optional parameter.
So You can select any chemical element to memorize or repeating just in the table!
brain_process
The main thing is not to overdo it! We recommend memorizing from 2 to 5 new chemical elements per day, and the rest of the time to devote to repeating the studied ones.
After successful memorization we will return you to the same position in the table.

This section contains useful tools for solving various chemical problems, easier information retrieval, etc.
Search table

For example, our Search table gives you the ability to find items by their property values, it is a very flexible and practical tool that allows you to work with groups of items. At same time you can tag element an click the switcher button in the right up corner to show only selected elements
Ok, I'll show how to use it. Put the tag on two chekboxes near the elements that you wanna to choose.
tag_chekbox_example
Then drag the switcher to the active state, there must only two elements lefts.
switcher_btn_example
After that, we want the only thing left on that list to be gases. So in search field, write ¬´Gas¬ª or just ¬´G¬ª and let's see what remains.
search_example
Now you need to clean your search by pressing the cross button in a search field, then press ¬´Presets¬ª button and chose ¬´clear all¬ª
Ok, lets look on another situation. For example you wanna chose only polyatomic nonmetals. So press ¬´Presets¬ª button and chose ¬´polyatomic nonmetals¬ª
presets_btn_example

Now imagine that you want to see the resulting list in order of, say, atomic mass ascending or descending. Chose optional parameter clicking ¬´gear button¬ª and chose atomic mass parameter, and click ¬´order button¬ª
order_btn_example

Order button have three states:
- unordered
- ascending order
- descending order
Try to click those button couple times after this lesson. And now lets look how our situation changed by pressing this button.
descending_order_btn_clicked
Search tools also has a memory, so it remembers your chosen chemical elements that you tagged and selected and optional parameter to show.
By the way, you can share some chemical properties of element to your contacts by pressing the element just in array and then pressing the share button. Try it!

This section contains educational materials on chemistry on different themes. These lectures feature interactive questions that help users better understand the content. We don't just ask questions, we teach you!
roman_lectorium

As part of the training, it is quite normal to ask questions and give wrong answers to them. Don't worry, in lectures you can answer until you have chosen all the correct answers, which can be one or more.

value.text: Have you figured out how to answer the questions?

answers.description: This is one of the 'correct' answers, it green colored or have positive prompt. Are you sure it's all clear?
Here more than one correct answer, try to press one more ansewr button. This button is red colored. All red colored answers are 'incorrect' or gave neagative prompt.
Great! After clicking all 'corrects' answers you can't tap other answers. And, wait a second, here must be some salutte!
Even if you choose all the wrong options, the question will remain open until you give all the correct answers.

structure.value: Reactions üåã
Of course, what kind of chemistry can you study without experiments and without carrying out chemical reactions?
lesson_one_romans_reaction

Although it is necessary to know the theoretical material, with personal participation comes a more visual understanding of what is happening and how it should be. And you must agree, it is much more interesting to observe the reaction live, and even more so to carry it out yourself.
In this section, you will do just that!

value.text: Do you think you carry out chemical reactions in your daily life?

answers.description: Even stirring sugar in tea is a dissolution reaction. In addition,if you don't eat sugar, your stomach oxidizes food under the action of hydrochloric acid and enzymes, so you are essentially a mobile laboratory yourself!
